tr.td:
69M with PMHx DM, asthma, HTN, cholelithiasis, fatty liver, HLD, obesity here for initial GI consultation for hepatic steatosis. Based on imaging and risk factors I suspect probable NAFLD. He does drink heavily on occasion and this may be contributing especially if under reported. There is no history of HCV, Wilson's disease, or common medications that cause secondary hepatic steatosis. We discussed the underlying pathophysiology and natural history of hepatic steatosis in detail. Importantly, we reviewed that the most common causes of long term morbidity and mortality in patients with NAFLD are sequelae from cardiovascular and metabolic disease. However some people will have progressive liver disease, which can lead to cirrhosis and HCC. Significant fibrosis and multiple features of metabolic syndrome (especially diabetes, which he has) appear to increase the risk of progressive disease. There are currently no FDA-approved medications. We reviewed that the cornerstone of management is dietary and lifestyle changes aimed at sustained weight loss.
- schedule surveillance colonoscopy
- Fibroscan to evaluate degree of steatosis/fibrosis
- FIB-4: need liver tests at next visit
- encouraged weight loss with goal >5% of total body weight (may reduce steatosis) and preferably >7-10% (may limit/reverse histologic features of steatohepatitis); we reviewed strategies to accomplish this, including following a Mediterranean diet with caloric restriction and routine exercise
- alcohol should be avoided
- if there is evidence of chronic liver disease, will exclude other common causes (hepatitis B/C, ANA, ASMA, AMA, immunoglobulins, iron profile, A1AT, ceruloplasmin); note that non-HFE related dysmetabolic iron overload can be observed in the setting of NAFLD, as well as mild elevations in autoimmune indices
- a GLP-1 agonist can be considered in those with DM and/or obesity if appropriate
- RTC 4 months

Patient presented to the GI office today 2023-12-27 for routine follow up of fatty liver disease but reportedly left due to "pain" to go the emergency room before being roomed. No visit took place. See prior GI consultation note for details. Will put on recall list to reschedule office visit.

HPI Notes: CC: new visit for fatty liver HPI: Anthony reports that he is here to address his liver. He notes that his back is bothering him today since he woke up. He has been trying to improve his diet and lifestyle. He now eats veggie pasta and avoids carbs and rice. He tries to avoid candy and red meat. He is eating more shrimp with stir fry instead of red meat. He is also trying to increase his intake of chicken. His peak weight was 258 lbs. He is currently around 207-210 lbs at home. However he has a goal to lose additional weight. He denies symptoms of hepatitis including jaundice, scleral icterus, changes in urine or stool color, edema, abdominal distension, abdominal pain, fever, malaise, vomiting, confusion or delayed thinking, easy bruising, or bleeding. GI History reviewed: COL 2017: 2 small TAs US renal 9/2022: echogenic liver parenchyma, left renal cyst Labs 2022: last A1c 7.4, plts 315, no recent liver tests for review Meds: as documented + daily ASA81 SHx: once in a while only on vacation alcohol (for ex on cruise in Dec he drank daily 8-9 drinks per day); but he doesn't drink at all when home; never smoker; disabled since 1989 after vertebral fracture requiring fusion FHx: mother with DM and also had liver and heart disease; sister with heart disease; father with emphysema

HPI Notes: CC: f/u fatty liver HPI: First seen 2/2023. Trying to improve diet and lifestyle, veggie pasta, avoids carbs and rice, candy, red meat. Peak wt 258 lbs. Last visit around 207-210 lbs at home. Goal to lose additional weight. No liver related sx. Plan for repeat liver tests, Fibroscan, surveillance colonoscopy. -- Patient presented to the GI office today 2023-12-27 for routine follow up of fatty liver disease but reportedly left due to "pain" to go the emergency room before being roomed. No visit took place. GI History reviewed: Labs 6/2023: ALT 40, AST 18, AP 78, Tbili 0.5, LDL 98, plts 296, A1c 8.1, HCV ab neg COL 3/2023: hemorrhoids otherwise normal, repeat 7 years recommended Fibroscan 2/2023: CAP 330, E 9.5 kPa COL 2017: 2 small TAs US renal 9/2022: echogenic liver parenchyma, left renal cyst Labs 2022: last A1c 7.4, plts 315, no recent liver tests for review Meds: as documented + daily ASA81 SHx: once in a while only on vacation alcohol (for ex on cruise in Dec he drank daily 8-9 drinks per day); but he doesn't drink at all when home; never smoker; disabled since 1989 after vertebral fracture requiring fusion FHx: mother with DM and also had liver and heart disease; sister with heart disease; father with emphysema
